reviews.reviewDate: The manufacturer commented on the review below
reviews.reviewText: I have been using a Russell Hobbs kettle for years and years so when it quit last week I ordered another. I just received it today and what a disappointment. The stainless is MUCH thinner than my last kettle and it is a lot louder when heating up. The second HUGE disappointment was the giant plastic bulb that backs up the temperature gauge. What were you thinking?? Who wants to boil water every morning in a stainless tea kettle that has HUGE piece of plastic in it. I mean come on. Why go with stainless then? First of all, I love the kettle. It looks great. It would make an impressive and much appreciated gift, especially for a housewarming or shower. It came well packed. It was bigger than I expected, it's twice the size of the Walmart plastic kettle I had been using.

Here's a few stats. I plugged it into a Kill-a-Watt meter and found that it uses a pretty constant 1330 watts while heating. There is no resting power drain whatsoever when it's off. (I live off-grid so these things are important for me to know. My plastic kettle used 900w but was slower to boil.) It took just over two minutes to boil 2 cups of room temperature water.

I love the temperature gauge. Very handy for stuff like green tea or hot chocolate where you don't want it boiling. Not too thrilled with the interior plastic parts as others have mentioned. The little plastic water level paddles are a cool idea but I just think using a measuring cup is easier. And they'll be difficult to clean around. I'm not tooooo worried about plastic, after all I was using a plastic kettle before, but it seems an odd choice to use plastic parts in a kettle designed to appeal to the stainless steel crowd. The other issue I have is that the kettle is thin metal with no insulation. It gets HOT. I checked the outside temp and it was 192 degrees. It's a small gripe I guess, but be aware of it.

All in all, it's a really nice kettle.

reviews.reviewTitle: Hot Look...but also hot to the touch
reviews.reviewDate: The manufacturer commented on the review below
reviews.reviewText:
I would like to recommend this product, but I can't. Sure it is easy to clean, easy to use and from what I can tell it should be fairly durable...but that means nothing if you skip some other basic product design elements.

This is on the higher price point and I feel like the product quality was completely skipped. The visual aesthetics are strong, it is vintage looking and I absolutely love this visual design. Where it fails is in the quality of product: two major factors here, the first being the noise level, this thing is definitely loud, louder than my dishwasher and probably louder than my washer/dryer. The second product oversight is the temperature in which this kettle gets, it WILL burn your hand should you touch anything but the handle of the kettle.

This product would be a better fit for its price point if it had addressed the noise and temperature which I'm assuming could be achieved as other electric kettles have by insulating the core. Had I known this, I would have purchased a different vintage looking electric kettle.

reviews.reviewText:
This product seems about the same as any other electric kettle as in, it does the job. I do appreciate the temperature gauge feature since I just learned that you should brew different teas at different temps.

Good features~~
*clean look, not modern clean but clean simple look (shiny, I like shiny)
*brings the water to a boil quicker than the stove which is fine, not in a big hurry but no complaints and it shuts off automatically. I put refrigerator cold filtered water in to the limit and it took two minutes so it's pretty quick if that matters to you.
*ergonomically comfortable--it is not heavy even with the water. By the look, I thought it would be heavy but not so. The handle is comfortable and secure feeling.
*plentiful volume at 1.7 liters (main reason I wanted one since my little gooseneck stove top kettle is barely a liter)
*doesn't spatter when boiling. Does get hot to touch so beware if you have little people, hairy counter walkers or forgetfuls around.
*easy as anything to clean (wide opening in the top and easy to remove lid)
*recommendation is to clean with a good soak of vinegar monthly to keep the hard water from mucking up the works (seems reasonable)

Meh features~~
* I expected to be more excited about the look and feel but it is just so-so. I would never pay the full price at around $80. This is no better than a $30 Hamilton Beach or similar. I ordered one from amazon warehouse that supposedly had a bit of minor damage to the lid or side but there is no damage--got lucky.

More good than Meh I guess. If you love the look, the functionality is what you would expect.

reviews.reviewDate: The manufacturer commented on the review below
reviews.reviewText:
While I have never owned a Russell Hobbs product in the past, I knew the company had a good reputation for utility and durability. So my expectations were set fairly high.

With a newly remodelled kitchen with a black and white and some grey colour scheme, this retro style electric kettle looked like it would fit right in. I like retro design and thought that even though the kitchen remodel is pretty modern, the black exterior would fit in as well as provide some visual interest with the retro/modern contrast.

The construction of this kettle left me disappointed. It just seems light and a bit cheap. The previous kettle, a Cuisinart which was still working without any issue, was much more substantial.

Others have commented on the water level window's position, but I don't have an issue with that. The Cuisinart's window is also located behind the handle, and I had no problem reading up the water level.

"Missing" features is that there is no temperature set and keep warm capabilities. Yes, I know the product description is clear and there is no mention of those features. However I think they would greatly improve this product's usability even if the price was increased. Not all tea types should be brewed with boiling water, and pour over coffee should NEVER be brewed at boiling! Having a temperature control and keep warm is almost essential.

All this said, this kettle has been performing well, the analog temperature gauge is very cool and the style is a complement to the kitchen. I'd give this 3-½ stars if I could, but I can't give it 4 because I think the manufacturer missed the boat a bit.

reviews.reviewTitle: Attractive kettle that is convenient and solidly built.
reviews.reviewText:
I've been very pleased with this kettle after using it heavily over the past few weeks. Operation is single-button simple, the kettle heats water quickly and retains the temperature for a decent length of time, and the enamel-like finish is very attractive.

The kettle is a large vessel, but the weight is balanced in such a way that you can fill and pour without giving yourself carpal tunnel syndrome.

My favorite feature is the low-profile heating base the kettle rests on. When the water finishes heating you can remove the kettle from the base, but the base itself remains completely cool. This is a nice feature, as you aren't leaving behind a hot element to worry about.

This kettle is a pleasure to use, and well-worth the price.

reviews.reviewTitle: Looks really cool, but has shortcomings
reviews.reviewText:
This is a good water kettle overall, but it could be improved. First, the good. It looks awesome and has sparked more than a few conversations in my office, where I use it. Everyone loves the retro styling. The shape is cool, the mixed red and stainless is cool, and the analog temperature gauge is cool. It also works pretty well overall and heats water about as quickly as any other I have used. The temperature gauge also seems to be pretty accurate. It also has some nice design features, such as a fill level indicator by the handle, a lid that's easy to take on and off, a good non-drip spout, and little indicators inside that show how many cups you have poured in. Overall, it has nice features.

But there are a few features I don't like quite as well. First, although I'm not super persnickety about plastic in my kettles, the large plastic "bubble" around the temperature gauge is prominently on the inside. It's a lot of plastic touching hot water. In addition to the leaching of chemicals from plastic (most people's concern), I also wonder if it will start leaking eventually into the analog gauge. Second, the temperature gauge has a big metal rod sticking through the interior of the pot. This makes thorough cleaning somewhat harder and also stands the chance of breaking eventually. Finally, although it's a cool kettle, the price seems a bit high at $80. It would be a much better sell at $50 or so.

Overall, a good kettle, but could be improved, especially for the price point.

My last kettle was a glass model with a single button to start and boil only feature without a temperature gauge, plus it had a hinged lid with little plastic parts that broke after 8 years. With the lid swinging loose, it was a burn hazard and needed to be replaced. I read every review on almost every brand available. I wanted stainless and analog with a single button to start. This Russell Hobbs fit my requirements and it arrived in a timely manner as promised. The lid is secure and doesn't fall off or get loose. The gauge is large and easy to read for making green tea or beverages that don't need 212 degree boiling water. We did not want the digital because of an elderly relative who would use the kettle and might have some confusion over pressing buttons or reading small digital interface. A single button to push on and she can use this to make our twice a day pot of tea with great ease. The window in the side is the only caveat, the markings are black on a clear window making it slightly difficult to read. One could mark with a label or paint pen if needed--we just wear our reading glasses. Some reviews commented on the red plastic measuring gauges on the inside for 1-3 cups of water, but they can be removed easily if plastic is not wanted. The stainless is holding up well, the red is cheery and the handle has ridges which make gripping easy. I am very well pleased with this kettle.

NOTE: we have very hard water in our region that leaves white marks on everything, but I filter my water and get little mineral build up.

This electric kettle from Russell Hobbs is good looking and works wonderfully. This electric kettle is part of the retro collection, and it looks beautiful. This kettle has a distinct style that is reminiscent of kitchenware from the 40s and 50s - very cute vintage look. The one I have is black with shiny silver. There is a temperature gauge on the front of the unit that displays the temperature of the water inside the unit. This is important because, while black tea needs boiling water to infuse, green and herbal teas need a temperature less than boiling for optimal taste.

The handle is heat resistant, and there is a filigree spot to rest, and it is very decorative and a beautiful detail. The lid comes off entirely to enable filling, and there is a small button under the handle that turns the kettle on. It shut's off automatically when the water reaches boiling.

In the inside of the kettle - which is all mettle - there are 3 red markers that indicates 1, 2 or 3 cups and promotes a rapid boil. Ideal for a quick cup of tea, a single serving of soup or oatmeal. The kettle operates smoothly and effectively. Water reaches boiling pretty quickly, about the same as any other kettle performs. The pour from this kettle is smooth (there is a filter at the spout that is easily removable and cleaned) and there is no drip - and I actually tried to make it drip, without success.

There are electric kettles that cost less than this, but very few look as beautiful as this. Form and function combine beautifully in this kettle.

With the Russell Hobbs Retro Style Electric Kettle, you have to love the retro look. This is what this kettle is all about. It heats water very quickly though there are kettles that are quicker and many are much slower. The spout works good and gauge reads the water temperature as you are using it. The handle is comfortable and the lid stays put. The temperature gauge works as it should.There is absolutely nothing wrong with this model.
That having been said...here's what I don't like about it. The lid is not hinged so it must be removed when filling or cleaning and set aside. The lid snaps on very loudly which is a problem for me in the early morning with a sleeping wife.
We have very hard water and must clean kettles and the like often. The inside of the kettle has three little plastic paddles on a rod which are used as 1, 2, and 3 cup measures. You can tell the amount of water being put in from the faucet by using these paddles. They are really in the way for cleaning and are of no real use for me. There is also a rod which goes from the temperature gauge to the middle of the kettle. This is stationary and would have to be cleaned around.
The Retro Style Kettle is very elegant looking and does have the retro look. It looks great on the counter, but I much prefer one of Russell Hobbs other styles.

The retro style electric kettle was a great addition to our kitchen. I had a different brand kettle before, but I like this one more as the style and rich red color fits our kitchen’s red oak wood. It heated very quickly and was very quiet too. The temperature gauge is really cool! One thing is didn’t like about this, and something must be done to address this, was the lid. It is very difficult to put the lid on and to take it off. It makes a loud sound when I take it off or on and if I do this at night, it can wake my kids up. Please address this.

What a bright and cheery note for your early morning tea. This is a thoughtfully designed hot pot which holds 1.7 Liters of water. It will boil a full kettle of water in a little over 7 minutes but many times I only want a cup of tea and this has been ingenuouslyprovided for. Inside the pot are 3 different plastic markers to show you just how much water to put in. This certainly speeds up the heating process and saves energy. There is also a easily visible temperature gauge on the front of the pot to show you just how hot the water inside is becoming. I didn’t know that green tea really needs only 160 degrees for brewing whereas my favorite, black tea, requires a full boil at 212 degrees.
The pot has a drip less spout which is very handy as my present one drips hot water on me while I pour out its contents. There is a removable filter at the spout which keeps scale out of your beverage.
This is an excellent value for the price and is cheery to boot. This is a nice addition to your kitchen

reviews.reviewTitle: Helps you cut down on coffee by drinking tea!
reviews.reviewText:
Written by my son in college:

I decided to get a kettle so that I would be more inclined to drink tea instead of coffee, and so far it is working. This kettle is small and compact, and a great addition to my dorm room. It has cup measurements on the inside(can measure 1-3 cups of water) so that you can boil as much water as you need. Another great feature of this kettle is the temperature gauge located on the outside of the kettle. Cons

The handle is cold to the touch once it is down boiling and the top is actually quite hard to take off. The paint has not chipped and the metal exterior looks great and it is a very cute kitchen gadget to have. The cup markings inside the kettle are useful and there are markings on the outside on the side near the handle too.

This one has a temperature gauge so you can get the perfect temp for your tea—green tea tastes best if you don’t boil the water. Black tea is best with boiling hot water. I love this feature. It’s also great for instant oatmeal.

It heats the water up very fast—much faster than heating water on the stove.

This kettle is also great because it will auto turn off when the water boils, or if there is no water left in the kettle—so no burning the pot.

The kettle is stainless steel, and very sturdy/very well made.

Retro good looks, comes in black or natty red
Good size, holds plenty of water 1.7liters
Seems fast (didn't compare times, stay tuned)
Easy to use--press lever, no programming
Temp gauge tells you how hot water is

Cons:
No warm hold at temp
No shut off at chosen temp (i.e., 180 for white tea)
Plastic parts inside, idiotic tabs for volume, plastic on sieve that catches any gravel from hard water.
Price, at almost a benjamin, you could do more

reviews.reviewText:
I was hoping this lovely looking retro kettle by Russell Hobbs would have, as appears from the outside, a smooth inner stainless steel lining for boiling water. Unfortunately, the pot has some areas where your boiling water is touching plastic while boiling, as you can see from my pics. The red "quick boil" level measuring plastic pads sticking out inside allow you to measure 1-3 cups of water to boil when you want fast hot water for a small number of servings and don't want to wait for a whole pot of water boil, and luckily, this is removable. However, there is an inner plastic cup section over the temperature gauge area that is fairly large and permanent. A side water level view in plastic shown on the outside under the handle, is also in contact w the hot water. If this is important to you, just be aware that this is not plastic-free boiling water.

That said, this is a good sized and serviceable pot, that heats water quickly, looks very pleasing and has a large, easy-to-grip handle. There is also a removable mesh filter on the pour spout, that will keep loose tea out of your cup. The pot turns off easily (on/off lever pops up) when your water boils, and it's great to have a dedicated boiler like this for quick hot drinks. Overall, this is a nice electric boiler, and depending on your desire for a full metal boiling interior, may or may not fit your needs.

I like that it isn't digital, There are plenty of digital temperature gauge tea kettles out there, so that makes this one unique! I had a Russell Hobbs tea kettle without a temperature gauge for about 7 years. It still works great, I just wanted an extra kettle- I really make a lot of tea. And I wanted this style because it has character!
My only dislike is the filter. It pops out soooo easily. It's nearly impossible to install. Then when it's finally in, I close the lid, and it pops right out again. I just put it away, so I'm not bothered with it. I really would have liked to use it with the kettle.

Says "Stainless Steel" there are Plastic parts in the part you're boiling water. The product feels incredibly flimsy compared to the sturdiness of the picture. It DOES boil water quickly. But probably FAR more than you need. Sure you can put less water in but I think everyone would have a much smaller kettle taking up counter space and simply boil water twice in the event you need 8 cups of tea (which is about what this giant kettle has space for.) Overpriced may be subjective but there is no other electric kettle at this price range that doesn't at least have several boil options and features. This one basically boils water. The temperature gauge is pretty cool but it's only an aesthetic feature. You can't set the temperature.
Made in China, don't buy!

reviews.reviewDate: The manufacturer commented on the review below
reviews.reviewText:
I use my electric kettle multiple times a day in the kitchen and have made my way through a couple from lesser known brands before finally settling on a Kitchen Aid KitchenAid KEK1722SX 1.7-Liter Electric Kettle with LED Display - Brushed Stainless Steel. This kettle is very close in price to the Kitchen Aid at the time of writing this review so I was curious to compare the two.

Russell Hobbs is a well known brand in England while it may seem fairly new in the US market and they are known to make reliable appliances.

Temperature gauge and time to boil : Time to boil is pretty comparable, with the Hobbs being slightly quicker, and the heating process is very quiet. The temp gauge is pretty cool since it looks like an old style boiler gauge. However, you have only one option with this kettle - boil. There is no hold warm function and no way to have it automatically heat to variable temperatures depending on the tea you are brewing.

Physical build : I do like the Empire red look on the Russell Hobbs but the lid is a pop off sort as opposed to a hinged top on the Kitchen Aid. Also, the Hobbs is much lighter to hold which may be a plus for some. A negative for me is that the Hobbs has the heating element exposed inside the kettle. This makes it a bit more difficult to clean around and will be a perfect spot for calcium deposits to build up. The Kitchen Aid has a concealed heating element which gives you a smooth bowl to clean.

Volume Gauge : There are two ways to measure how much water you have in the kettle. You can either see it in the transparent gauge inside the handle or you can use the red snap on piece inside the kettle to fill it to exactly one or two cups. I very rarely use the gauge on my kettles since I can usually tell by weight how much I have in it but the gauge on the Kitchen Aid is much bigger and shows more gradations than the one on the Hobbs.

Filter : this may seem minor but you are going to have water deposits in your kettle and you don't want them ending up in your tea cup. The filter on the Hobbs is not as snug or as well built as the one on the Kitchen Aid. It is quite flimsy and snaps into place instead of sliding into grooves so, with heat and repeated use, I can't imagine it will last terribly long.

There is a fair bit of plastic inside both kettles and I know a lot of us try to avoid that. I have included a picture of the inside of the Hobbs so you can see the large disc covering the gauge.

In sum, the Russell Hobbs is a very good looking and perfectly fine serviceable kettle but, in the price range, you get a lot more bang for your buck with other electric kettles. Were it a bit cheaper I would definitely rate it 4 stars.

This retro style Russel Hobbs tea kettle is amazing in both looks and performance. It is a beautiful thing to see on our kitchen counter. The bright red color combined with the shiny chrome gives the kettle an elegant appearance.

The no slip handle makes it easy to hold and there is a removable lime filter back of the spout.

The kettle is extremely well made and it heats water quickly. It is much faster than a pot on the stove. I have said the thing is built like a tank and shows typical British quality.

The kettle will shut off automatically when the water in it boils or it can be stopped heating by turning it off when the easily seen gauge on the front of it reaches a point you like. There is a small indicator light under the handle near the base that shows power on or off.

When the Russel Hobbs kettle arrived we retired one of those high tech electric tea pots with all of the settings, LED screens and popup lid.

That elaborate kettle worked well after studying the owner’s manual for a week or so, but the Russel Hobbs is the epitome of simplicity and much favored.

To operate the new kettle it is only necessary to take off the lid, fill the kettle with the amount of water preferred, replace the lid and push the power lever down. What can be easier than that?

Do I recommend the Russel Hobbs electric tea kettle? You bet I do.

I have used electric kettles for years. In my house they are much more than just a convenience and in use several times a day.

An electric kettle is something you didn't think you'd need until you have one... and then wonder how on earth you ever lived without it. No more kettles boiling dry on the stove because you got side tracked, no more being stuck in the kitchen waiting for the water to boil to avoid the former. And we all know that when you watch a kettle on the stove it takes twice as long for it to finally boil.

This is where electric kettles shine: they bring the water to a boil and then shut off. The better ones are insulated and keep the water hot a lot longer than the flimsy glass kettles. So if you forgot about it you just push down the switch and in a minute or two the water is back to boiling.

This electric kettle from Russell Hobbs stands out both by its different and very appealing looks and also by its functionality. Having a temperature gauge built in is actually a very smart idea since you don't always want boiling water (for hot chocolate or cocoa, for instance, or for baby formula). You still have to watch it, of course, and shut the pot off when the desired temperature has been reached. Or you can just let the temperature drop down to the desired temperature.

The pot is insulated, so no burned skin when accidentally touching it. That is a huge plus for me. The wider footprint prevents the pot from being knocked over. And the top opening is wide and makes for easy cleaning to prevent lime buildup over time.

This a high quality pot which I expect to give me years of service. Should any interior rust spots appear, an issue with some pots I had throw out, I will amend my current rating.

First of all, this electric kettle is beautiful! It is rather large, has a very substantial handle that is easy to grasp. Sits on a flat round element that you plug in to heat. When water has reached boiling, the unit automatically shuts off. You lift the kettle off the element to pour. You turn it on my pressing the switch at the bottom of the kettle. It boiled 3 cups of water in 3 minutes. There is a dial on the front that has a thermometer so you can see how fast it is heating, and what the temperature is. It holds a lot of water, so you can make a full pot of tea, and more. There is a window on the outside to show how full it is. There are also 3 red plastic "dots" on the inside that show 1, 2, or 3 cups, which makes it easy to know how much water to put in. Easy to clean since the lid comes off and the opening is large. I like this feature. My old kettle had a very small opening so it was hard to reach in to clean. This kettle is so elegant looking and works great. I highly recommend it. It is just for boiling water. To make tea, you would pour the water into a cup or a tea pot to steep. Would not recommending steeping the tea in this kettle, just use it to boil the water. It would make wonderful gift for the tea lover in your family. See my photos for a closer look.

For some reason I decided to try a new Brand & model just because there now are SO many options even though it made me feel a bit guilty as the AROMA had served me so well for so long.

I also know that this Brand has been popular in England forever. I'm also a bit disappointed that it doesn't boil as fast as my old Aroma and again, this probably has to do with the amount of water in the large cylinder tank.
Bottom Line: While I do like the look of the R Hobbs Retro, I miss my Aroma (1.5L) because it was faster to boil; also to fill; smaller on the counter and lighter to pour. I think when the one at my other House finally goes, I'll replace with the Aroma again. The price of the Aroma is substantially less expensive.

I purchased this kettle a few months ago, and have been very pleased with the outcome. This kettle is ideal for the person who is in a pinch for time, but doesn’t want to use their microwave to heat their water. Aside from its retro design, the features that make this kettle stand out from the others are as follows:

Water temperature gauge
Quick boil indicator
Drip free pouring
Removable, washable filter

When filling your kettle, you will find that there are three “quick boil indicators,” which can be seen from above. These allow you to quickly fill the kettle with one-three cups, depending on how much you want to have. These are incredibly helpful when you’re unsure how much a cup or mug can hold - just fill your cup with water, pour it into the kettle for heating, then pour it directly back into your cup.

There is a temperature gauge located on the front of the kettle, so you can look to see how hot the water is. When water has reached peak boiling temperature, the lever located on the side of the kettle switches it off. This feature ensures safety for your household, and minimizes the likelihood of a kitchen fire. The water stays warm for a good ten minutes though, so there’s no need to worry about it being too cool to steep tea or another drink of your choosing.

Speaking of pouring, the Russell Hobbs website states that the pour spout is designed to keep the boiled water from spilling or leaking, thus keeping your hands free from any burns. You will find that this is 100% true, as water comes out in a steady stream and does not leak from the airtight lid.

When you are finished using your kettle, you can remove the anti-scale filter (located in the pour spout) for cleaning. The filter prevents limescale from falling into your cup, making for a cleaner, more pure drink.

Once again, this kettle is great for the person who is in a hurry. It is stylish, easy to use, and easy to clean. You will find that it fulfills all of its promises, and will save you precious time.

One advantage with this electric kettle is that the red plastic water level indicators inside help me measure precise amounts of water to boil at a time whereas I do occasionally over fill the manual kettle for my morning beverage.

A second advantage with the Hobbs kettle is the water temperature gauge. If I don’t brew my beverage right away the gauge tells me the water temperature so I know if it’s still hot enough for my brew.

It takes exactly three minutes to boil three cups of water and the kettle switches off when it begins to boil. Boiling water covers the red plastic water level indicators but I don’t worry over that. After all I have microwaved food in plastic containers for years with no adverse effects to date.

This kettle sits well on a base that is separate and connects to the wall socket. The lid fits tightly. The spout has a filter and is replaceable. The kettle is very easy to use right out of the box and I like it.

Honestly, I'd give this more stars if I could. Not only does it do exactly what it says it will do, but it is super fun to look at. I love the crisp, clear red with the chrome. For me, it's not so retro as I didn't grow up with an electric kettle. But I appreciate the aesthetic a lot.

There are not a ton of pieces to lose. You have the heating plate, the lid and the screen at the spout. Just keep on top of keeping that clean to reduce the scale build up (if you live in one of THOSE areas like I do.)

It heats fast. I can pop it off to pour my tea water at the right temperature thanks to the easy-to-read dial on the front. Even my husband, not a fan of anything on the counter, likes the way this kettle looks.

Heating a full kettle takes ages - much longer than a much lower prices T-Fal unit. You could certainly boil a pot of water faster on an electric stove.

I've also used some kettles abroad that heat in a fraction of the time it takes this one, so this observation is based on using multiple kettles from multiple manufacturers.

I found the lid especially tight fitting.

The plastic water level indicators are of some concern to me: what might they be leaching when in contact with the Universal Solvent.

Overall - the design looks nice on the outside but the walls are thin and get hot and it takes too long to heat.

It's the Retro that got me. It's the excellent performance that keeps it on the counter.
